Did you run into an issue?
Please file a bug for this. If the ansible code doing the templating which is passed here thinks all subnets on a network have the same subnet mask, that is a bug.

We encountered issue in spine-leaf deployment which have different subnet mask used for base network and its subnet. In this case, we see the one from base network is always passed to <network>IpSubnet parameters even the node belongs to subnet instead.
~~~
- name: InternalAPI
  name_lower: internal_api
  ip_subnet: '192.168.10.0/24'
  ...
  subnets:
    internal_api_leaf_1:
      ...
      ip_subnet: '192.168.11.0/25'
~~~

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This appears to be untrue:

http://logs.openstack.org/36/605436/4/check/nova-tox-functional-py35/66bf4c1/testr_results.html.gz

I'm told it actually does fix this specific bug, but introduces another that causes the same test to fail in a very similar but distinct way.

p'tayta p'tahta.
It is true, but this patch breaks an assumption in that test which causes it to fail differently. Fix coming shortly.

Specifically, the functional test previously assumed that both rebuilds would execute _do_rebuild_instance, because the validation happens after that. However, this patch changes that because we now validate before calling _do_rebuild_instance. The fake call (fake_rebuild) previously arbitrarily made the instance on host1 wait, but because this now happens after validation and therefore only on 1 host this became a race.

However, I can't actually work out what this delay is for. The comment says:

  # Simulate that the rebuild request of one of the instances
  # reaches the target compute manager significantly later ***so the
  # rebuild of the other instance can finish before the late
  # validation of the first rebuild***.

(*** around what appears to be the justification). However, I don't understand why that's important, or how this delay achieves it. Specifically I don't understand:

* why it's important that one rebuild is completely finished before the other is validated.

* why, if we want to wait for a rebuild to finish, we're waiting on rebuild.start.

However, I do think it's important to have 1 thread delay here if we wanted to guarantee correctness, but for an entirely different reason: we need to guarantee the scheduler race. We want to guarantee that the scheduler will send both instances to host3, thus requiring the late validation check that we're testing here. This means that we don't want one rebuild to finish so completely that the next rebuild isn't sent there in the first place.

Note that the existing code doesn't guarantee that either because the instance on host2 will never delay. Therefore it could, theoretically, win the scheduling race so completely that the instance on host1 is never sent to host3. In practise this seems extremely unlikely, and in 250 local runs of this test it hasn't happened.

However, for the sake of correctness I'll fix it anyway rather than just removing the delay entirely.
We set the instance.host in instance_claim() before we return the claim and then enter that context, where we do the late check, right? In what way are we setting it after the late check?

In the case of evacuate, we run ComputeManager.rebuild_instance(), which does a rebuild_claim, which doesn't set instance.host.  We then call _do_rebuild_instance_with_claim() (which in turn calls _validate_instance_group_policy()) and if that passes we set instance.host.

Based on the above, the servers that are building should just fail their check when they go to do it. Since we synchronize the method that actually sets instance.host, no two instances will get their host set at the same time. If the concern is just that there is a gap between setting hosts and doing the check, couldn't we just yield out of instance_claim() while holding the RT lock so that we do the check stuff while locked?

...what Chris said above: we do this differently for build and evacuate. Both cases previously had problems: build was safe but sub-optimal when given multiple concurrent builds[1], evacuate had this bug.

The purpose of this patch is to fix evacuate, but in doing so we also fix the problem in build.

[1] If you got 2 builds concurrently, both would take a claim, then both would fail the late validation check, leaving neither building on the host.
s/the/them

nova/compute/manager.py.message: shouldn't we still keep the original lock for this case?
No. It wasn't locking anything.

Unfortunately I don't think we can do this.  Suppose we have max_server_per_host=2, zero instances on this node to start, and two instances being checked at the same time.  In that case, both should pass.

The ugly solution would be for the second to block waiting for the first to give up the lock.

A faster but complicated solution would be to keep track of the number of in-progress operations on this node for each group and factor that into the check against "max_server_per_host".
Turns out it even makes it a bit simpler :)
Good point. My first solution did actually wait. Tracking the number of in-progress builds would not be complex.
Why kill this comment? Is it not still true, with regard to the ordering of the nested_contexts?

No, it's not true any more, and in fact I explicitly flipped the order if you look at (new) line 2147.

The build behaviour (as opposed to rebuild) has always been safe, but sub-optimal. When we took the claim we updated instance.host to the current host, so when we later ran the check the accounting was accurate *assuming all builders would succeed*. That meant that if multiple builders all took a claim, they could then *all* subsequently fail the check.

Because we now account for in-progress builders in the check itself this is no longer required, and in fact either order is still safe. However, if we flip the order to do the check first then we also fix the problem of failing all concurrent builders. Now if we get N concurrent build requests, when the check runs they haven't updated instance.host yet so we're only accounting for the ones which passed the check. That means we now allow the correct number to proceed up to the max.

TL;DR Previously the old order was required for safety. Now it's not, and I flipped the order to handle multiple builds more efficiently, as well as consistency with rebuild.
I think maybe the yield and builders.remove() could use comments, to minimize confusion for the casual reader.
I've added a better comment at the top, and some context here.
+1, it would be nice to just make it easier for readers of this code.

This is neat, but I feel like it might be a little overkill and thus more obscure than it needs to be just because it's generic.

If it were me, I would just make a context manager that specifically takes the two contexts that we care about, and grabs them in the same order. It would make this smaller, and very much more readable.

Just something stupid like:

 with gp_ctxt:
     with claim_ctxt:
         yield

would do the trick. It also has the benefit of helping to make sure that future use or refactoring of this code does not switch the order of arguments so the build pulls the contexts in one order and rebuild pulls them in the other, leaving us with a deadlock whenever they do compete.

If I messed with this, I think I'd prefer to go with Sean's suggestion of pulling test.nested into utils and just using that. It would also be cumbersome to write a simple, hardcoded solution which also took account of gp_ctxt being possibly None. I'll have a think about that, though.

The order thing is interesting. Because we don't hold a lock during execution I don't think we can deadlock, but the order is still important to correctness.
This should be something in lockutils.
so here we create a lock object but dont aquire it

I thought about that, but it just seemed like unnecessary indirection. The lockutils still is useful for multi-process locks, and locks used in multiple places which form a kind of 'internal api'. However, the only interface exposed is a decorator, which is super kludgy when you don't need that. 

This is about the simplest possible use of a lock.

then we aquire the lock here because eventlets
may context switch us in this block.
specifcally we could yeild here.
To clarify, sean is pointing out that eventlet could cause a context switch here.

You're leaking memory here. It's small, but it's a leak. Since the user chooses this value and it can be 255 bytes long, I can trivially consume 255 bytes (plus the overhead of an empty set) of compute node memory at a time, over and over.

Hmm, I'd mentioned this myself in a previous version, but it hadn't occurred to me that these are user-defined. Yeah, that's bad. It's also much simpler to clean up in this version, as you point out below.

If the thing we're yielding to raises an exception, we will never remove the thing from builders, which means we might make poor decisions later (and or this could grow unbounded with enough time).

You need to do something like:

 try:
     yield
 finally:
     # Build has completed: success or failure. Either way, ensure it is
     # removed from the in-progress set.
     with self._group_anti_affinity_check_lock:
         builders.remove(instance.uuid)
D'oh.

if not builders:
     self._group_anti_affinity_builders.pop(group_hint)
I would expect to see new unit test coverage for this method that pokes all of the potential failure points, like the raised-an-exception case mentioned above.
Ok.

nova/tests/functional/regressions/test_b.message: im not sure why you are making this atomic just to intentionally write a race.
I definitely don't understand why we need this and why we can't just use a mock to determine which order things happened in.
If it wasn't atomic then it would be possible for both threads to acquire it, and then this would be a deadlock.

See a missive I wrote about this on an earlier version of the patch. The previous version of this was very broken, and I've essentially tried here to reverse engineer the original purpose and write that.

We don't care what order things happen here; we care about timing. It's no good just to check mock later to see what order things happened, because we don't care. We care that whichever thread is scheduled first, it doesn't complete until the second thread is also scheduled here.

In the actual test, we do:

        # evacuate both instances
        post = {'evacuate': {}}
        self.api.post_server_action(server1['id'], post)
        self.api.post_server_action(server2['id'], post)

In order to ensure that the race we're trying to test actually occurs, we need to guarantee that the first evacuate doesn't complete entirely before the second evacuate runs.

Incidentally, this code is what caused the recent uptick in the incidence of this test in CI. Before the fix to fake_notifier we *never* waited here, so the race almost never occurred, so we weren't testing it. After the fix to fake_notifier, we only tested the race if the instance on host1 landed first, hence the approximately 50% failure rate.

This code guarantees that we always exercise the race by setting using a flag. We use an atomic flag because we're multi-threaded[1].

[1] (For Sean ;)): I know you can do this without a lock if you assume eventlet and encode implicit assumptions about the conditions under which eventlet will context switch, but that way lies insanity and really-hard-to-find bugs. E.g. when you later add a new context switching method into the middle of what you forgot was a critical section, or when we ditch eventlet and all assumptions change. It's way simpler just to assume a context switch can happen anywhere and write defensive code.
Incidentally, this line isn't strictly necessary as we never re-acquire the lock and it'll just go safely out of scope. It's tidier, though.

octavia/controller/worker/v1/tasks/ampho.message: When an amp in an active-standby topology is in ERROR, the associated LB operating status should be DEGRADED. This is important for visibility/SLA reporting to non-admin users who do not have read permission to amphora objects (hence neither to their statuses).

My suggestion is to set the *operating* status to DEGRADED. That status value exists already today: https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/load-balancer/v2/#operating-status-codes

The provisioning status should be left untouched. Its status should already be PENDING_UPDATE when this code runs.

That would be a big change to our current status information. We currently do not have a "DEGRADED" provisioning status: https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/load-balancer/v2/index.html#provisioning-status-codes
I'm not saying that isn't an option/idea, but would be best in it's own feature patch.

octavia/network/drivers/neutron/allowed_.message: amp_configs will be returned empty and post_vip_plugin will raise an AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'vip_subnet/vrrp_port'.

The point of this change is to not revert the flow if one of the ports is missing from neutron. We want it to passively fail (marking the amp as ERROR) such that if this is a two amphora load balancer one can be repaired even if the other is missing in neutron.
You will note that the other two tasks that call this method all pass in an amphora, so they will not go down this code path and will still raise the exception in the above if block. Only the GetAmphoraeNetworkConfigs task, which is used in the VRRP subflow only, will not pass an amphora in.

Granted, this is a subtlety in the code. I guess another option is to split get_network_configs into two methods, one that iterates over the amps and one that doesn't. Do you have a thought on how to make this more clear?

I did not empirically produce this.

1. AmphoraIndexVRRPUpdate in VRRP subflow requires AMPHORAE_NETWORK_CONFIG provided by GetAmphoraeNetworkConfigs just before in the flow (it calls this method).

2. The case of neutron losing a port in-between is unlikely to happen, yes. Though, if get_network_configs raises an exception (e.g. due to momentary connectivity glitch with Neutron API), the flow will only fail later in AmphoraPostVIPPlug.

So you are relying on amp_configs-consuming tasks such as AmphoraIndexVRRPUpdate and AmphoraPostVIPPlug to revert the flow when the returned amp_configs from this task empty. I think we should trigger a flow revert from this task if the returning amps_configs is an empty dict.

How did you produce that? It's called only in two places
1 The VRRP subflow, which is after post_vip_plug.
2. The get_amp_net_subflow where the port was just created in the same flow (and the amp is passed in, so it will be the only result). If neutron loses a port between two points in the same flow, I think revert is probably the only option right?

Uhm, yeah, no. I don't have a problem setting specific "name" columns to use utf8mb4, but under no circumstances do I want to see any defaults (for the schema or the tables) set to utf8mb4.

It's already a performance problem that we use three *times* as much storage than we actually need for columns that store UUIDs because we set the default database and table column charset to utf8 (3-byte default in MySQL).

This 3X storage requirements means index scans and searches are 3 times slower, require 3 times more resources to satisfy in the query plan, and generally just slow things down for no reason at all.

There was some discussion in the nova irc channel yesterday that altering the charset of a column probably violates the constraints on what a migration may do. Altering the charset of a column may require that the table be rebuilt, which takes time and thus would cause downtime. I suspect this is a concern that will need to be researched and confirmed or denied before we can go much further on this idea.
Will we eventually also need to Alter Database?

The IRC discussion was actually triggered by this idea - in Cinder we're having almost the same set of constraints for DB migrations.

In general that would mean that in case of Nova it would require creating new columns and moving data there as a live-data-update.

In Cinder we would need to stretch similar effort through 3 releases. This would mean if we start work in X release, we get the functionality working in X+1 and finish all the cleanups in X+2. It may be possible to shrink that to 2 if we would be smart enough, but I'm 100% sure such approach is actually feasible.

You are right, all schemas (aka databases) are utf8. You can verify this with. 

select * from information_schema.schemata;

While the process of database migration is complex in a highly available system (and a separate dicussion), adding new columns and moving data inplace has several critical disadvantages that make it impractical in a system of any volume.

1. It takes more diskspace.
2. For columns that require indexes it takes even more diskspace.
3. Removing the columns at the end does not reclaim that diskspace.
4. For a MySQL environment that does NOT use innodb_file_per_table, you cannot get this space back with an entire dump, destroy and reload of ALL databases.

No, this does not truncate the underlying data. It only truncates the value of the data that is stored in the btree leaf nodes. Infact it can be hugely beneficial to limit index length to a number that reasonably identifies a small (e.g. 1-5 rows) of data. This can reduce the actual on-disk size of an index by up to 50%. This saving, translates to more information in memory, and fastest query execution.

However, this technique does not work for unique indexes.

InnoDB in MySQL 5.5 supports that concept of an online ALTER statement (see https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.5/en/innodb-online-ddl.html).

However while in theory it's great, in practices it comes with limitations (which get better in 5.6 and 5.7) and with issues depending on how you got to MySQL 5.5 (e.g. did you upgrade) etc.

There is one critical architectural design that is missing from the OpenStack schemas (at least when looking at a devstack environment).

Not all columns need to be utf8, and therefore do not need to be modified to utf8mb4 in the first place.  

The following information is why.  I was not involved in OpenStack database design, nor are these points considering that OpenStack uses an SQL abstraction layer and an oslo.db library.  These may be limitations of capacity technically, or procedural y (e.g. a rule to be consistent for the sake of consistency).

I share this information because to design an optimized and performant large MySQL system, these points can have a large impact across sizing, backups, performance and the are therefore a big deal in a larger more concurrent system.

For this example I will use the glance.images.checksum column (because it's a table in devstack with some data).

This column is defined as 

`checksum` varchar(32) DEFAULT NULL

the column in indexed (important for this discussion)

KEY `checksum_image_idx` (`checksum`),

and the table is

ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8

A sample value is 8a40c862b5735975d82605c1dd395796

checksum is a MD5 string of 32 bytes.  MD5's as we know ONLY store hexidecimal characters, (it can never be utf8).  

On disk, MySQL stores this optimally at 32-35 bytes, however in memory this is 99 bytes long.  That's 32 bytes x 3 bytes per character (utf8 datatype) + 2 bytes because it's VARCHAR, and 1 more byte because is is NULLABLE.

The optimal datatype for this column in CHAR(32) CHARACTER SET latin1 NOT NULL 

Because, quite simply this is 32 bytes of memory for the indexed column, not 99 bytes.  You may ask, big deal a few bytes. However when across dozens to hundreds of indexed columns in a database with millions of rows in tables, on a machine with a finite amount of RAM, the impact can mean queries running 10x slower.

Again, I caveat this comment with how to ideally design a MySQL database schema. In life however we make compromises, and some that may be applicable to OpenStack include, the lack of a data architect, an SQL abstraction layer, rules to enforce consistency and complexity of upgrading an existing product.  Many of these can be overcome with the right investment.

How about instead of forcing the deployment to use whatever we think is right for them, we change openstack to work with whatever the deployment has configured. So if the deployer wants text columns to be utf8mb4 they can set that as the default for their database (or migrate existing tables) and openstack will work. We could have the db commands (like keystone-manage db_sync) fail with an error and require a --force parameter if they have a crazy setup like myisam or a small charset (latin1 or whatever).

Though I think this approach is Ok.
But we have some attached complexities to this approach.

In different components we have schema validation to restrict 4 byte unicode charset.
If we provide "On demand" migration to deployer, we have to think about schema validation as well in same way.

For ex, if deployer decided to go with utf8mb4, then we have to remove schema validation for utfmb4 and if deployer decides to go without utf8mb4, then we have to keep schema validation for 4byte unicodes.

This is one example, there would be some other cases as well.
So, it seems good to go in predecided approach instead of pluggin type support to deployer.

One issue with letting deployments decide for themselves whether they support utf8 or utf8mb4 or just latin1 or whatever else is that it means that the interfaces presented by different clouds will behave differently. On the one hand this is okay: you try to do something get back a 400 with the right message, fix what you're doing, go from there, no biggie.

On the other hand: 'But I want to name my thingie "☃man" at all my public clouds'.

So to a certain extent what we're talking about here is consistency in the exposed interfaces and how important that is.

oslo_utils/secretutils.py.message: Remove the '_' as this should be a public method that gets used by client code.
It may be worthwhile to reference the upstream Python FIPS issue here: https://bugs.python.org/issue9216

Maybe we should check explicitly for

    if data is None:

here?  That way other falsy values would still be passed.  e.g. Passing something like

    secretutils.md5(b'').digest()

Won't throw away that empty byte string.

OTOH, maybe we need a fancier way to tell whether the data arg was passed in or not?  If we want to emulate hashlib.md5 exaclty, then checking for None is not enough because:

    hashlib.md5(None)  # raises TypeError

but,

    secretutils.md5(None)  # returns an MD5 HASH object

I think it would be better to rename this parameter to 'string' to match the upstream hashlib.md5 signature.

    Help on built-in function openssl_md5 in module _hashlib:

    openssl_md5(string=b'')
        Returns a md5 hash object; optionally initialized with a string
The function logic may be easier to read if we move this if statement outside of the try block right before the return in the last line.

Then he/she can run the second command without sudo but this chown fails because the log file exists with root:root owner and that time and non-root user can't chown it without explicit sudo.

I guess I could move this to after the playbook was executed so that we’re catching all cases. The thought was to catch it when the file exists, though I can see there may be some issues with my thought process. I also considered adding a touch when the doesn’t exist. Maybe I’ll do both?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: A link to https://help.github.com/en/articles/about-code-owners could be useful for the reviewer.
Is the API v4 also has this limitation https://developer.github.com/v4/object/pullrequestchangedfileconnection/ ?

Yes it does. I tried it out:

- the field "changedFiles" on PullRequest gives the correct number of changed files in the PR even if it's more than 300 (see https://developer.github.com/enterprise/2.15/v4/object/pullrequest/#fields)
- but the PullRequestChangedFileConnection gives only up to 300 files.

releasenotes/notes/evaluate-codeowners-d.message:
'all CODEOWNERs' seems like it might be a bit strong. ansible/ansible uses a *similar* file (although not codeowners) - but it's an example I have at hand:

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/.github/BOTMETA.yml#L177
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/.github/BOTMETA.yml#L1586

In this case, everyone in $team_openstack are 'codeowners' for that code. We don't want to require a review from every member of the team before merging, but instead we look for 2 positive review from those people.

Do we want to teach zuul about number-of-codeowners? Or do we want to just have zuul ensure that if there are reviews from codeowners they are all positive? Or am I completely misunderstanding the situation?
Or something like: ... will now only performed if reviews according to codeowners rules are available if requested by the branch protection.

You're understanding it right, we require at least one review of a code owner for each modified file.

The number of codeowners was not a thing when this was implemented. I'd like it to be supported but in order to make this change not even more complicated (it's hard to get it right and probably even harder to get reviewers) I'd like to defer that to a followup-change that adds this new feature.

That said we're running this in production since several weeks now and I think we've shaken out most bugs given that our users are quite good in finding corner cases.

Cool. Then I think we should update this release note to say "now only be performed if at least one approval from am appropriate user from CODEOWNERS is present."

Or something.

roles/revoke-sudo/tasks/main.yaml.message: This is going to requires the SETUID capability which is an issue for restricted environment. To work around the wheel group issue, you can also do that at the image level, basically moving the sudo wheel permission to the /etc/sudoers.d/zuul file. Here is an example: https://softwarefactory-project.io/cgit/config/tree/containers/centos-8/Dockerfile#n27
Yep that was the idea, as we should not rely solely on our own images... not to mention that even our own images do change and we do not run all zuul-jobs tests on them before updating them.

It's got failed_when: false though - so if it doesn't work (in a restricted env) it's probably fine, yeah? I like the idea of doing this for cases when someone might be using an unmodified centos-8 image via cloud-init or something similar.
That is not backward compatible, in software-factory we are already working around that hardcoded path by setting a file named '/etc/sudoers.d/zuul' even when the user is named differently.
Also see the discussion at: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706262/
This will fail if "{{ ansible_user }}" revokes sudo and the zuul file exists.
Look at line 21: ignore errors. At this stage we ignore errors, the only real test is last task, where we effectively validate that sudo no longer works.

docker/macros.j2.message:
Since the introduction of PY3 version as the main version on CentOS/Ubuntu, they distinctly install them using python3.X release and named pip with a version in order to avoid collision on systems still using PY2.7 such as CentOS 7.x and at least until 1 january 2021.

So I just decided to keep the pip_version and call that one as someone can decide (for whatever obscure reason) to stick with a specific 3.6 or 3.7.3 for instance.
Yep for now, but I do prefer to get a way for the futur to quickly update if we ever have specifics such as 4.x or 3.Y fixed etc.
anyways, interesting that there was no pip link - we are using virtualenv so there should be one
it should call the desired python with `-m pip` rather than this

I've just keep what was used before in previous release and didn't changed that for a direct module call because I didn't wanted to have a long change discussion over this patch that rather focus on the python/pip installation process.

Of course I could propose a second change later on but I think that if we force the module usage it will imply a lot of pain for those that want to stick with a specific version.
agree, in a python3 world , we can use python3 -m pip directly. just replace {{ pip_version }} to python3 -m pip. and remove the installation of python-pip3

kolla seems doesn't support customize versions of python now. this value used at kolla-ansible  https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/master/ansible/group_vars/all.yml#L1092 

at train we support py27 and python3, but this patchset apply on master branch only, not train， on train branch we might need add a check for py2 or py3

I've initially created this patch to be backward compatible with train, I'm creating a generic bug to be merged on master, then backport to required branches.

I've made the appropriate changes on the current patch set to only support PY3.x serie tho.

What about people willing to use a specific python 3.x version? You'll need to call {{ distro_python_version }} -m pip which is really the same than having a pip variable.

If you don't install python3-pip the python pip module won't be available with CentOS release, so it won't work.

Just stick with what distribution provides and let people have their custom versions if they want, it's just a matter of a variable that already exist.

With the current notation, both, customers with specific version and us as a generic solution are happy.

Don't forget that we still have train supported that use both, PY27 and PY3X.

Is it really OK to remove this condition?

Seems that it will consider a volume as multiattached, even when len(attachment_list) == 1.

I would still make this:

    if attachment_list and len(attachment_list) > 1

But that's really just a personal preference.

I asked Ajitha and he said it's ok to leave it this way.

I also think it's more pythonic to omit `is not None`, but it's not mandatory.

There're several occurences of such conditions in this file. It may be addressed in another patch, if there's an interest to do so.
